pros: Opportunities to learn: Working as a research assistant in NUS provides an opportunity to gain hands-on experience in a specific field and to develop new skills and knowledge. Mentorship: People around you, etc. Profs and other RA's, are very nice. You can work closely with them and can receive valuable mentorship and guidance from them.
cons: As RA, generally, you may have limited autonomy in your work and may have to follow specific instructions and procedures set by supervisor or principal investigator

pros: Pros are highly dependent on the leadership style of your Head of Department and their willingness/ability to fight for staff benefits, promotions and workplace flexibility. Generally, the university offers good amounts of annual leave and the library is world class.
cons: Archaic and unjust human resource management that is decades behind international best practice. Dysfunctional promotion and tenure processes that fail to promote women and local faculty; works best for foreign appointments of senior male scholars looking to escape their underfunded universities in the US, Europe and Australasia. Treatment of E&P administration staff is even worse than faculty. Don't bother coming in unless you're senior enough to negotiate good conditions and benefits, and you don't need to make your way up through the ranks.

review_title: Beware, dont come here, dont accept the scholarship
pros: Academics, some brilliant and nice profs here
cons: Management and admin staff are either oblivious or incompetent. Top down style management creates unreasonable or straight up impractical measures. Sometimes they require you to do certain things or else there will be dire consequences, but they themselves mess up things so bad that it becomes impossible for you to perform these tasks. This is bizarre and even hilarious if i wasnt a student here. Rules for Phds are very strict yet often unclear. Admins dont even have an answer most of the time when asked to clarify. People who arent academics do the absolute minimum. They want to get you here then sweep you under the rug. Many things that would be reasonable or even necessary for your long term career development that would just be the norm at other schools are not allowed here. This is not worth it, even with scholarship. This can ruin you in the long run. They just churn out clueless people with a degree. Go to another school.

review_title: Extremely heavy workload that destroys work life balance
pros:
1. Most people in the department are extremely nice to work with, very helpful to newcomers.
2. Pay is average or slightly above average.
3. Very good medical and leave benefits.
cons:
1. The workload is absolutely insane in my office. Might not be the same at other offices but it is definitely not what I expect from this office. The amount of work done does not translate to equivalent results in terms of engagement of alumni. Very few from NUS actually know of this office and participate in the activities, yet there is so much to do. Operating at "full capacity" yet staff are OT-ing everyday to get things done.
2. Turnover is extremely high, most executives leave within 6 months, with few lasting 1 year. That's a major red flag.
3. Boss is antagonistic and not receptive to any feedback at all. Wants you to present but questions and shoots down anything that comes out of your mouth.
I hope this helps anyone out there who is looking to apply and if you read carefully, you will know which office this is.

review_title: Lack of a career path spoils an otherwise generous employer
pros: Singapore is an attractive city to work in because it is a travel hub with many options to travel to all parts of the world for conferences and visits of family. It also offers genuine travel attractions regionally, though it is itself an uninteresting tourist spot. Living in Singapore is expensive mostly because of rent and this is where the NUS housing subsidy in its various forms helped. Food is cheap if you don't wine and dine and so is public transport. Don't get a car, it is absurdly expensive. Paperwork can be tedious and frustrating due to their inexplicable love for acronyms. But as with other advance Asian nations, things move smoothly once everything is set. Taxation is very low, but do pay attention to what is written between the lines (read good guides). Health care is good if it is covered by the employers. Else, it is horrifically costly. Beware.
cons: In the early days there were generous housing subsidies which is essential for an expensive city like Singapore. Then the policy makers decided to return to subsidies back to NUS books by allowing staff to stay at a discounted rate in their staff housing, with the shortfall to be paid from the grant of their bosses. Overall, this greatly reduced the attractiveness of NUS as an employer (whose idea was it to build those fancy apartments in the first place?). Research wise, it was one of the better places in Asia to work in. However, there was a chronic lack of a clear career path for non-PI's, especially for international staff, that really dampen my NUS experience.

review_title: Great first job out of university, but progression stagnates after a while
pros: There is work-life balance and flexibility, but the job definitely has crunch times. The job of an RA differs across disciplines and I largely think that it is very dependent on the immediate principal investigators and co-investigators managing the research project. I had the opportunity to work with a professor and a like-minded team who I believe are doing great work, as well as in collaboration with academic and non-academic partners. I was able to work on refining and developing new research skills.
cons:
Not much progression if you do not take up additional duties (e.g. TA duties) or pursue a Master’s concurrently. Unlike many fresh graduate programs out there, the academic career path is more self-guided. Need to ask yourself what taking on a RA role would allow you to learn and how it contributes to your career development. 

Sometimes it did feel like I was only doing a job and not much emphasis on career tract progression and learning and development as an employee.

review_title: Good for some, bad for others - depends on what you're looking for at this stage in your life
job_title: Manager, Marketing and Communications in Singapore
pros:
- Great colleagues and an understanding reporting officer who understands the challenges on the ground, and the need to go bigger and do better

- Pace of work can be slow if you compare it to start-ups or even the public service sector in Singapore. Some people have called this a retirement home, and it may be a good place for you to rest your (weary) soul after years of slogging it out elsewhere.
cons:
- Very little room for career growth and movement up the corporate ladder.

- Lousy renumeration, and can be perceived as stingy when it comes to awarding bonuses. 

- Increasing frequency of having to deal with bombs that drop on your lap on a Friday but needed to be done the Thursday before. Ie lots of last-minute tasks with ridiculously-short runways.

- Presence of 'divas' in top positions whose words are gospel and who tend to rule with an iron fist, making it extremely difficult to - whisper this - suggest or implement changes.

- Very little incentive and motivation to find new ways of marketing the university, especially at a time when the university needs to break new ground and attract more students besides the undergraduates

review_title: Some spaces to innovate; the rest is all about the bureaucratic walls
pros:
- I was fortunate to have a boss who allows me to think outside the box and pursue them 
- My supervisor has an open-door policy philosophy. I could open up to her and discuss my plans and goals.
cons:
- It is a mission-driven organisation but there are a lot of walls you need to break. Different departments and faculties are still working in silos, and are very protective of their portfolios.
- In my previous rotations, I had colleagues who would usually 'steal' my idea and repackage it as if it was their own - typical Singaporean workplace culture which I found very unsupportive. Therefore, I would only keep some ideas and not share it with everyone unless I found a good sponsor to work with me on my projects.

review_title: Not a healthy environment (for E&A in Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine)
pros:
1. Good health benefits, and always get corporate discounts/offers.
2. Next to Kent Ridge MRT.
3. Affordable food (student-priced).
4. Good work-life balance. You can come on time and leave on time.
5. Welfare is good - always have meals/parties to celebrate events as a department, like Chinese New Year, Christmas, etc.
cons:
1. Incredibly slow-paced work
2. Politics everywhere. It'll trickle down to the employees, and lead to them being used like chess pieces in their boss' political game without regard for the relevance of work the employees are forced to take.
3. Extremely old-fashioned. Old professors rule the world here, and they do not like change.
4. Pay isn't great. Below average.
5. Common to have your boss take credit for your work. It didn't just happen to me, but it happens to a lot of people all across this school. You can work for a long time on something, then your boss will take it and present it at a meeting while removing your name from the PowerPoint slides. Then they'll bask in all the praise. It's just the culture here. It's a thing they all do.
6. Women may not feel comfortable working here, what with all the peeping tom and sexual harassment cases arising from NUS. Personally, I am constantly checking my surroundings when I use the toilet. lol
7. Low or no career progression.

review_title: Looks nice outside, but inside is a whole other ballgame
pros:
Pay is on time.
Staff can utilize gyms and swimming pools on campus.
cons:
Senior in department is clearly in name only. She is highly unapproachable, doesn't teach you things and just refers you to the SOP in the shared drive, which may or may not be updated. If the work cannot be found in the SOP, she will say "oh, I never do before also leh", leaving you hanging. Granted, I am not expecting her to hand-hold (as what my superior had told me that I would be, seeing that I'm totally new to the job, but hey, talk is cheap, or should I say, free), but at least point me in the right direction or correct me if I'm wrong before doing something that would exacerbate the matter... but her attitude is a total eye-opener.
If you encounter a problem at work, don't bother to go and ask around the department on helpful advise that may benefit you. The colleagues are all working in silos - they wouldn't know what you are working on and vice versa. And because of the workload (the department is severely short handed - I've witnessed mass resignations of an average of 1 - 2 staff per month leaving), it is really crazy. I get mini panic attacks every time an email comes into my personal work account/the department account/the section email account, hoping and praying that it is not something/a fire I have to put out. 
Appraisals are usually very one-sided, top-down manner - they will nitpick on all of your mistakes, and will skim over your achievements.

cons: The pay is not that great, very little benefits and you don't really have much in the way of career progression; a lot of the quality of the working environment depends on your direct supervisor and your working relationship..I had a good experience with work-life balance but based on what I've seen that's not guaranteed

review_title: A high end university with little humanity
pros:
A well equipped university, with highly skilled individuals. All fields are represented, and the campus is quite new (compared to EU).
Singapore itself is very convenient to live, friendly to (western) foreigners.
cons:
There's close to zero humanity. Especially in a PhD or graduates programs.
There is no effective bounding between students, most student activities are limited to undergrads (you anyway won't receive most emails).

In most research labs, students don't even befriend with each other, so the feeling of loneliness is tangible as soon as you assist at the usual weekly meeting for research updates of each student of a professor's lab.

The school is quite traditional. Internships, summer programs, exchanges etc aren't encouraged.

Your work-life balance, as well as your PhD duration is very dependent on your professor. Some professors will want to keep you 5 years or more, just to get teaching help and more publications from you.
The official minimum is 3 years, which actually never happens. The duration usually varies from 4 to 5.5 years, and you will need to find a source of income once the scholarship ends (4 years).

pros: NUS is a great place to work at. While it's a big organisation of course and each department / office can vary, I would say the work is meaningful as you feel like you're making a real impact in society (whether directly or indirectly). As an established employer, NUS' processes and systems are already firmly in place so there is a lot of stability. Good work-life balance. Progressive culture when it comes to training and career opportunities for employees.
cons: Because of age and size, it can be quite hierarchical and not as organic / dynamic as younger institutions.

review_title: Big organisation but old school thinking
pros:
- Work-life balance
- Benefits are good
- Canteen food is cheap

cons:
- Lofty mission of educating/transforming the society but what management cares about are the numbers and performance; staff welfare is not a priority and overlooked

- Constant emphasis on digitalisation but department heads have been stuck in their roles for years and are not willing to listen and slow to change
